trial_identification.studytitle: Effectiveness of Tai Chi for people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does short-form Sun-style Tai Chi improve exercise capacity in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?: a single blind, randomised controlled trial

interventions.interventions: Sun-style Tai Chi exercise training Short form Sun-style Tai Chi is a low-impact exercise which involves both upper and lower limb. This form consists of 21 moves in total and it was designed by Dr Lam, who is a general physician and Tai Chi master in Australia. The duration of the course is 12 weeks (2 times per week for 12 weeks, about 1 hour each time) Assessments, for exercise capacity, muscle strength, balance and health related quality of life, will be performed at baseline and also after 12 weeks Tai Chi training
interventions.comparator: The control group has no Tai Chi training. All participants will continue their standard medical care for the duration of the study - 12 weeks. Pulmonary rehabilitation including exercise training and education will be offered after the study

primaryOutcome.outcome: exercise capacity - measured by the edurance shuttle walking test
primaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline (week 0) before randomisation and at the end of the study (at week 13)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: health related quality of life - measured by chronic respiratory disease questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline (week 0) before randomisation and at the end of the study (at week 13)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Lung function, lung volume and diffusion capacity - measured by full lung function test
balance - measured by a series of balanace tests including semi-tandem and tandem standing, walking, sit to stand, single leg stance and functional reach test
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline (week 0) before randomisation and at the end of the study (at week 13)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: subjective physical performance - measured by functional performance inventroy questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline (week 0) before randomisation and at the end of the study (at week 13)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: the acceptance of Tai Chi - measured by a subjective feedback questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at the end of the study (at week 13)

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Neurological, acute cardiovascular diseases and other conditions that might limit the safe participation for exercise testing and training in this study

trial_design.concealment: participants will be randomised after initial baseline testing by a computer program
trial_design.sequence: Stratified randomisation using a computer-based program. The stratification is based on forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) and gender

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The aim of the project is to determine the effect on Tai Chi training on exercise capacity in people with COPD.
Hypothesis: On completion of an 12 week training program, subjects with COPD will demonstrate significant improvement in exercise capacity, compare with the control group with no Tai Chit raining.
Significance: If Tai Chi improves exercise capacity in people with COPD this would provide an alternate form of exercise training which does not require exercise equipment thus making effective exercise training more accessible for the large numbers of people with COPD.
